title: Growing Tree Fruit in the Uintah Basin
author: Boyd Kitchen, Uintah County Extension Agent
disease_notes: Apples: S=susceptible, MS= moderately susceptible, LS= low susceptibility, MR=moderately resistance, R=resistant

plants.name: Empire
plants.description: Good pollinator. McIntosh type with better color, less bruising and stores better than McIntosh.

plants.name: Fuji
plants.description: Ripens too late for many areas in the Basin, but has been successfully grown in Lapoint. Stores well. Very high quality fruit. May require detailed pruning.

plants.name: Gala
plants.description: Excellent flavor, excellent for applesauce or drying. May require heavy thinning.

plants.name: Golden Supreme
plants.description: Similar to Golden Delicious, but ripens 1 â€“ 2 weeks earlier, annual bearing habit, less likely to russet. Uneven ripening.

plants.name: Honeycrisp
plants.description: Large dappled red fruit with good flavor, crispness and juiciness. Hardy in Zone 4. Stores well.

plants.name: Jonagold
plants.description: Very high quality fruit. Not a good pollinator, short storage.

plants.name: Jonafree
plants.description: Very firm. Fruit tends to be small, careful pruning to avoid small fruit.

plants.name: Prima
plants.description: Blooms later and may avoid late spring frosts. Short storage.

plants.name: Spartan
plants.description: Crisp, firmer than McIntosh. Small fruit, may drop prematurely, difficult to thin.

plants.name: Zestar
plants.description: Large, crunchy, juicy red fruit with sweet-tart flavor. Excellent for both fresh eating and cooking. Tree is vigorous, upright, but susceptible to apple scab.

plants.name: Harglow
plants.description: Blooms slightly later than most commercial apricots. The fruit is medium in size and bright solid orange in color; flesh is firm and flavorful. This variety is best suited for fresh eating.

plants.name: Hargrand
plants.description: Ripens in mid season. The fruit is a dull orange, but the size is excellent when the crop has been thinned. The flesh is juicy and tasty. Suitable for fresh eating.

plants.name: Harlayne
plants.description: Trees bloom late. Fruit production is heavy and fruit ripens late. Very hardy. The fruit has a red blush and is bright and attractive. Requires careful thinning to attain size. Suited for fresh eating but also suitable for home processing. The flesh is firm and fairly dry, and the mild flavor is fair to good.

plants.name: Manchurian
plants.description: This is the hardiest of the fruiting apricots.

plants.name: Moongold
plants.description: The golden fruits are medium size, sweet, juicy, ripen unevenly, prone to splitting, freestone.

plants.name: Sungold
plants.description: Fruits are small, mild, sweet.

plants.name: Perfection
plants.description: Trees are hardy and heavy bearing. Fruit is large, oval to oblong and flavorful. Flesh and skin are colored a bright yellow-orange with no blush. Good quality, firm-textured with early developing color. Needs cross pollination.

plants.name: Anjou
plants.description: About as hardy as Bartlett. Moderately resistant to fire blight.

plants.name: Bartlett
plants.description: Leading commercial variety in the west. May be partially self fertile. Susceptible to fire blight.

plants.name: Clapp's Favorite
plants.description: Hardy, fruit has sweet, fine flesh. Susceptible to fire blight.

plants.name: Flemish Beauty
plants.description: Hardy, fruit is firm and melting. Susceptible to fire blight.

plants.name: Harrow Delight
plants.description: Fire blight resistant.

plants.name: Luscious
plants.description: Fire blight resistant. Sweet, juicy fruit.

plants.name: John
plants.description: Fire blight resistant. Juicy fruit.

plants.name: Summercrisp
plants.description: Sweet flavored, crisp fruit. Fruit harvested when crisp, green with red blush, may be stored up to 2 months. One of the hardiest pear varieties.
